newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak NAFTA shares a sell - ING report.
newsitem.headline: Slovak NAFTA shares a sell - ING report.

text.p: Shares of Slovakia's largest oil and gas storage company Nafta a.s. are rated a sell after revising downward the 1996 earnings estimate for the firm, ING Barings said on Tuesday in an investor report.
"We have downgraded our 1996 earnings forecast and are recommending investors to sell their holdings (in Nafta) at the current price," the report said.
The recommemdation came when Nafta's price was 1,980 crowns. Nafta shares closed at 2,030 crowns on Monday, down 30 crowns from Friday's close.
ING representatives were not immediately available for comment on whether the recommendation remained the same given the issue's current price.
Nafta reported disappointing results in the first half of 1996, as rising costs clashed with an inflexible revenue structure, the report said.
Nafta posted a pre-tax profit of 409.104 million crowns for the January-June period.

"The key problem was sharply rising maintanence and repair costs in Nafta drilling and gas storage operations, which the company was unable to pass on to customers who enjoy long-term negotiated gas storage rates," the report said.
The report said this was the basis a cut in its 1996 full year profit forecast by 200 million crowns to around 510 million.
Another reason for the negative recommendation was the recent sale of the state's 45.9 percent in Nafta to a company unknown in the investment community.
In August the state privatisation agency, the National Property Fund, sold its entire holdings in Nafta to Druha Obchodna a.s., for a price far below the market value.
The new owner had to pay 500 million crowns, while on the Bratislava Stock Exchange the stake was worth around 3.2 billion crowns.
"Until more is known and understood about the buyer of the stake, we believe that the stock will be kept off most foreign investors' buy lists," ING said.
